title: 110_hr7227
content: The "Death in Custody Reporting Act of 2008" requires states to provide information on individuals who die in law enforcement custody. The "Death in Custody Reporting Act of 2008" mandates states to report quarterly to the Attorney General details of individuals who die while detained, under arrest, en route to incarceration, or incarcerated in various correctional facilities. Reported information must include the deceased person's name, gender, race, ethnicity, and age. The "Death in Custody Reporting Act of 2008" requires states to report details of individuals who die while detained, including name, gender, race, ethnicity, age, date, time, location of death, law enforcement agency involved, and circumstances surrounding the death. States have 120 days to comply with the Act, with possible extensions granted by the Attorney General. Compliance may be waived if it is deemed unconstitutional. Failure to comply with subsection (a) of the "Death in Custody Reporting Act of 2008" may result in a 10 percent reduction of allocated funds for the State under various crime control programs. The Death in Custody Reporting Act of 2008 mandates that failure to comply with subsection (a) may lead to a 10 percent reduction in allocated funds for the State under crime control programs. Amounts not allocated due to non-compliance will be reallocated to compliant States. Additionally, the Attorney General is required to conduct a study on reported information to reduce deaths in custody. The Attorney General must study the relationship between deaths in custody and management actions in jails, prisons, and specified facilities. A report with findings must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General is required to collect information on deaths of individuals in federal custody, including those detained, arrested, en route to incarceration, or incarcerated in federal, state, or local facilities. The report must include minimum information as specified in section 2(b) and the data will be analyzed for the study required in section 2(f).
